clinical_study.brief_title: A Brief Intervention to Improve Cost-effective Resource Use Among Medicine Housestaff
clinical_study.official_title: A Brief Intervention to Improve Cost-effective Resource Use Among Medicine Housestaff

collaborator.agency: Partners Center of Expertise in Quality and Patient Safety

brief_summary.textblock:
OBJECTIVE: To test a brief intervention designed to improve the cost-effectiveness of care provided by medicine housestaff for hospitalized patients.
HYPOTHESIS: A brief intervention in which medicine residents receive itemized bills for recent patients cared for by them, followed by a discussion on approaches to reducing unnecessary inpatient costs, can result in significant cost reductions without adversely affecting patient outcomes.

detailed_description.textblock: We designed a brief educational intervention with two primary objectives: 1) to increase awareness among residents about how their decisions impact the costs of inpatient medical care; and 2) to improve the cost-effectiveness of care provided by residents without adversely affecting patient outcomes. We hypothesized that a brief intervention in which residents receive bills for patients they recently cared for, followed by a discussion on approaches to reducing unnecessary inpatient costs, would reduce costs without adversely affecting patient outcomes.

primary_outcome.description: Total hospital cost per admission for 2 weeks following the educational intervention.
Total lab cost per admission for 2 weeks following the educational intervention.
Total pharmacy cost per admission for 2 weeks following the educational intervention.
Total radiology cost per admission for 2 weeks following the educational intervention.

secondary_outcome.measure: admission to an intensive care unit (ICU)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: within 30 days after end of study period
within 30 days after end of study period

arm_group.description: Residents Randomized to Receive Educational Intervention
Residents randomized not to receive a teaching intervention.

intervention.description: 45-minute teaching session on healthcare costs, in which each resident reviewed an itemized hospital bill for a patient he/she had cared for, followed by an open-ended discussion about reducing unnecessary costs.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Internal Medicine Residents on Inpatient Rotations at Brigham & Women's Hospital
Exclusion Criteria:
- Having a team member who was in either the control group or intervention group in a prior round of this study.
